title: WeWork saga just latest blunder at SoftBank
text:
SoftBank was once seen as a master of tech investing for buying early stakes in Yahoo and Alibaba. It is now better known for something else: a string of flops and its mastery of face-saving accounting wheezes.

The dumb money was not so dumb after all. Public investors rejected WeWork’s plan to float.

Instead, SoftBank — supposedly the smart money in tech — will double down on its investment in the controversial US offices business. The Japanese group will inject $US6.5 billion ($9.5 billion) to dodge a writedown and save face. The constituency convinced by SoftBank’s accounting manoeuvres is dwindling fast.

The investment group would wind up with 80 per cent of WeWork’s equity. Yet even with a majority economic stake, SoftBank would not take full control. It plans to redirect voting rights acquired from founder Adam Neumann to an expanded WeWork board. It will classify WeWork as an associate rather than a subsidiary.

Doing so attracts lenient accounting treatment. Without technical control, SoftBank does not need to record the investment at cost and later adjust it according to its earnings performance – or the lack thereof. Instead, because SoftBank may hold WeWork shares for transfer to its Vision Fund, they would be a financial asset measured at fair value. This is in the eye of the beholder for an unlisted stock.

SoftBank has been adept at registering increases in stakes, sometimes through transactions in small parcels of shares, that boosts the notional value of the whole. At SoftBank it contributes to reported group earnings which are also swelled by a share of paper profits from subsidiaries.
